title: Essential Calculus, a Revolutionary Approach to Teaching Calculus
text:
<jats:p>Classical physics is based on the mathematical analysis of differential equation models of physical systems.  Yet, because differential equations are an advanced topic, they are typically not taught until the second or third year at the university.   This paper describes a new approach to teaching calculus that covers differential equations in the tenth week.
</jats:p>

title: The Fast Track Introduction to Calculus
A logical calculus of the ideas immanent in nervous activity
An Introduction to the Fractional Calculus and Fractional Differential Equations
[MOBI] Communicating And Mobile Systems The Pi Calculus
Fractional Calculus
text: This paper aims to give the reader a comfortable introduction to Fractional Calculus. Fractional Derivatives and Integrals are defined in multiple ways and then connected to each other in order to give a firm understanding in the subject. The reader is expected to be versed in undergraduate complex analysis, meaning that they should also be familiar with real analysis. In the concluding remarks, the readers familiar with measure theory will find a brief discussion of how to extend the topics discussed in the paper to more general analysis.

title: The Malliavin Calculus and Related Topics
The Lambda Calculus: Its Syntax and Semantics
Applications Of Fractional Calculus In Physics
The calculus of consent : logical foundations of constitutional democracy
text: THE CALCULUS OF CONSENT was co-authored by Buchanan with Gordon Tullock, with whom Buchanan collaborated on many books and academic enterprises throughout their careers. As Robert D Tollison states in the foreword: (this book) is a radical departure from the way democracies conduct their business. The 'Calculus' is already a book for the ages. This classic work analyses the political organisation of a free society through the lens of the economic organisation of society. The authors acknowledge their unease as economists in analysing the political organisation, but they take the risk of forging into unfamiliar territory because they believe the benefits of their perspective will bear much fruit. As the authors state, their objective in this book is "to analyze the calculus of the rational individual when he is faced with questions of constitutional choice...We examine the (choice) process extensively only with reference to the problem of decision-making rules." The authors describe their approach as 'economic individualism'. They believe that economists have explored individual choice extensively in the market sector while social scientists have largely ignored the dynamics of individual decision-making in the dynamics of forming group action in the public sector. Written in the early 1960s, THE CALCULUS OF CONSENT has become a bulwark of the public choice movement for which James M Buchanan is so justly famous.

title: Multiple Integrals in the Calculus of Variations
The concentration-compactness principle in the calculus of variations. The locally compact case, part 1
An Extended Privacy Calculus Model for E-Commerce Transactions
The Fractional Calculus: Theory and Applications of Differentiation and Integration to Arbitrary Order
Direct Methods In The Calculus Of Variations
A new collection of real world applications of fractional calculus in science and engineering
Calculus on Manifolds
text: Description: The three higher-dimensional versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus – Green's theorem, the divergence theorem, and Stokes' theorem – that one encounters in a typical multi-variable calculus course have two paradoxical characteristics. On the one hand, these results lie at the center of many areas of mathematics and the physical sciences, including analysis of partial differential equations, fluid mechanics, electromagnetism, and thermodynamics. On the other hand, most students don't understand these theorems and almost certainly forget them after the final exam (I do not except myself from this category). The purpose of this course is essentially a semester-long study of the modern version of Stokes' theorem and the mathematics needed to build it up (Green's theorem and the divergence theorem are corollaries of Stokes). In fact, the mathematics we develop along the way will include topics that appear at the foundation of modern differential geometry and algebraic topology. The first part of the course will focus on calculus in higher dimensions: differentiation and integration of functions defined on R n , along with a basic study of topology in R n. We will see, for example, the implicit and inverse function theorems, Fubini's theorem, and the change-of-variables formula for integration. The second part of the course will introduce important algebraic objects that are used in geometry (e.g., tensors, differential forms, and singular chains), along with operations between them (e.g., products, exterior differentiation, and boundary chains). This will be done in the setting of R n , and we will see a version of Stokes' theorem here. The third part of the course will move to the setting of manifolds. A manifold is, colloquially, a space that, on small patches, " looks like R n " (e.g., a sphere, or the surface of a donut, or the entire donut when we allow for manifolds-with-boundary). Formally, it is helpful to keep the following in mind: calculus can be done in R n , calculus involves local analysis of functions, manifolds look like R n locally.. .therefore, calculus can be done on manifolds! We will make this rigorous by transferring our work from the second part of the course to the manifold setting. In the end, we will prove the following general version of Stokes' theorem and understand what it actually means! M dω = ∂M ω Textbook: We will follow Michael Spivak's book " Calculus on Manifolds " very closely. …
